title: Credit Report False Reporting - Can I sue ?
question: Recently I noticed on my credit report that I have a $10k account in collections since last September. The debt is not mine ! When I called the company, they told me to send in my credit report which "has my SS # on the front page." I had to pull my credit report from three places and NONE had my SS# on it. I called them back and after 10 min on the phone I offered to send in my SS card which has my real SS # on it.
answers: If you found an account on your credit report that does not belong to you, there are generally two possible reasons, and both require swift action. One, you may be the subject of a mixed file at the level of the credit reporting agencies, or two, the victim of identity theft. There are very specific actions you can take with regard to either issue, and they both start with a dispute of the account to the consumer reporting agencies. Your initial instinct to contact the creditor was correct, but this doesn't invoke some important legal protections that you have when you notify the consumer reporting agencies that the account is wrongly appearing in your consumer reports. I recommend that you make all communications in writing. Take it seriously, and be very cautious about sending any personal information to anyone at this point. I do not recommend sending it to the creditor yet. Tell the creditor that you dispute the account and ask it to validate the debt by providing you with information about it. I have more detailed information on disputing debts with creditors and consumer reporting agencies online which you may want to review--look at the Debt Collection and Credit Reporting pages. Also, you should immediately contact an attorney experienced in consumer reporting issues and debt collection matters before providing any information to the creditor. The National Association of Consumer Advocates maintains a website with a list of consumer attorneys that can certainly help you with this issue.

I agree with the comments of my colleagues. I would add that you should also get your credit report from the fourth credit bureau, Innovis - you will need to contact them directly to get your credit report. Dispute the erroneous reporting with all 4 credit bureaus, in writing. Attach a fraud affidavit. Send it via certified mail return receipt requested to all 4 credit bureaus.

I would recommend you consult an attorney who handles consumer credit matters before sending the dispute letters out.

Good luck.

NO NO NO. Do not send this collection agency anything. Since you live in California you are entitled to the protections of a more favorable state law. You don't even know this is a real collection agency, could be identity thiefs. Your social security number is usually redacted to four digits on your credit reports. You should never send you social security card to any collection agency.

I recommend you contact my office in Orange County for a free review of your credit report and the collection letters. Most likely, you can sue them under state law for reporting inaccurate information and recover up to $5,000. www.lakeshorelaw.org

Federal law (the FCRA) governs the activity of credit reporting agencies. Under the FCRA there are certain steps you must take before you have a viable claim. You are wise to seek legal advice.

For more steps on what you can do at this juncture, visit http://www.ohioconsumerhelp.com/sub/credit-report-errors.jsp.

If it is a debt collector you are speaking to by phone, be careful about the information you share and provide. I would also suggest sending a written dispute to the collection agency. Federal law also governs their actions (the FDCPA). Advise them that this is not your debt and you dispute any responsibility for the account. For good measure, tell them to send you validation of anything they have to attribute this account/debt to you. And tell them to stop contacting you, except to provide you the validation information. Put this in writing, make copies of EVERYTHING for your records, and send it by certified mail, return receipt requested. For additional information on how to request verification of an alleged debt from a debt collector, go to http://www.ohioconsumerhelp.com/sub/verification-letter.jsp.

If a lawsuit is filed against you, I would suggest you contact a seasoned lawyer in your area right away. Rest assured that many consumer advocates may offer representation on a contingency fee basis in a case such as yours. For skilled attorneys in your area, go to http://naca.net/find-attorney.

It may even benefit you to consult with an attorney at this time if the collection activity does not immediately cease, or if the errors on your credit report(s) is not duly removed.


Good luck to you!!
